header: ISD Political Readiness Assessment Tool — Designed by DB
welcome: Welcome to the Political Readiness Assessment

questions.text: When a complex issue like unemployment or waste management arises in your constituency, what’s your first response?

options.text: I bring together local experts and citizens to co-create solutions and implement them.
I study successful examples from other regions and adapt them locally.
I consult my team or local officials for advice and depend on their suggestions.
I wait for higher authorities or my party to guide or intervene.

questions.text: How often do you engage with research, data, or policy papers to inform your decisions?

options.text: Regularly, I actively seek out and use evidence-based insights.
Occasionally, when relevant reports are brought to my attention.
Rarely, I rely on my team to summarize key points.
Never, I trust my instincts or party guidance.

questions.text: How do you approach building coalitions or gaining support for your initiatives?

options.text: I proactively build alliances across parties and stakeholders.
I work within my party but reach out to others when needed.
I rely on my party’s leadership to guide coalition efforts.
I avoid coalitions and focus on my own agenda.

questions.text: How comfortable are you navigating political opposition or criticism?

options.text: Very comfortable, I engage constructively and find common ground.
Somewhat comfortable, I address it but prefer to avoid conflict.
Uncomfortable, I rely on others to handle opposition.
I avoid opposition and stick to safe topics.

questions.text: How often do you engage directly with your constituents (e.g., town halls, community events)?

options.text: Frequently, I prioritize face-to-face interactions.
Occasionally, when my schedule allows.
Rarely, I rely on my team to gather community feedback.
Never, I focus on higher-level priorities.

questions.text: How do you ensure diverse voices in your community are heard?

options.text: I actively seek out and include marginalized groups.
I listen to those who approach me directly.
I rely on my team to identify community needs.
I focus on the majority’s needs.

questions.text: How do you approach securing funding for local projects?

options.text: I actively pursue grants, partnerships, and innovative funding.
I work with existing budgets and seek some external funds.
I rely on party or government allocations.
I don’t focus on funding; others handle it.

questions.text: How confident are you in managing budgets or financial oversight?

options.text: Very confident, I closely monitor and optimize budgets.
Somewhat confident, I understand budgets but rely on advisors.
Not confident, I delegate financial decisions.
I avoid financial responsibilities.

questions.text: How extensive is your network of professional or community contacts?

options.text: Very extensive, I maintain strong, diverse connections.
Moderate, I have key contacts but could expand.
Limited, I rely on a small circle of trusted contacts.
I don’t actively maintain a network.

questions.text: How often do you leverage your network to advance your goals?

options.text: Frequently, I collaborate with contacts regularly.
Occasionally, when specific needs arise.
Rarely, I prefer to work independently.
Never, I don’t rely on networks.

questions.text: How do you handle ethical dilemmas in your political work?

options.text: I follow a strong personal ethical framework and act transparently.
I balance ethics with practical considerations.
I rely on party or legal guidelines for decisions.
I avoid addressing ethical dilemmas.

questions.text: How do you ensure accountability to your constituents?

options.text: I regularly report progress and seek feedback.
I address accountability when issues arise.
I rely on my team to handle accountability.
I don’t prioritize accountability.
